articles.headline: G.E.’s New Strategy: Less Is More
articles.snippet: John Flannery, the company’s new leader, offered new details about his strategy, along with disappointing third-quarter results.
articles.abstract: John Flannery, the company’s new leader, offered new details about his strategy, along with disappointing third-quarter results.
articles.lead_paragraph: A smaller, simpler and more efficient General Electric. That is the plan for the company’s future under its new leader, John Flannery.

articles.headline: Giving Away Billions as Fast as They Can
articles.snippet: A new crop of mega-philanthropists — from Soros to Gates to Koch — eclipses old guard, changes the rules and courts controversy.
articles.abstract: A new crop of mega-philanthropists — from Soros to Gates to Koch — eclipses old guard, changes the rules and courts controversy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Step aside, Rockefeller. Move over, Carnegie. Out of the way, Ford.

articles.headline: After Harvey Weinstein’s Fall, Spotlight Finds His Brother
articles.snippet: Bob Weinstein long operated in the shadow of his sibling, but is now scrambling to hold their company together while facing an uncertain future of his own.
articles.abstract: Bob Weinstein long operated in the shadow of his sibling, but is now scrambling to hold their company together while facing an uncertain future of his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: All his life, Bob Weinstein toiled in the shadow of his larger-than-life older sibling, Harvey Weinstein.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes, Rachel Abrams and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: Inside Amazon, Diversity Concerns Flare Up After Harassment Accusations
articles.snippet: Amazon’s handling of accusations of sexual harassment involving Roy Price, who ran its movie and television operations, has set off confusion, debate and finger-pointing.
articles.abstract: Amazon’s handling of accusations of sexual harassment involving Roy Price, who ran its movie and television operations, has set off confusion, debate and finger-pointing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon on Friday tried to quell concerns among employees about sexual harassment accusations against an executive, sending an email to its staff saying the company would review its policies to ensure that “they are doing their job to provide a harassment-free workplace.”

articles.headline: Body Cameras Have Little Effect on Police Behavior, Study Says
articles.snippet: An 18-month study of more than 2,000 officers in Washington found that those with cameras used force at about the same rate as those without.
articles.abstract: An 18-month study of more than 2,000 officers in Washington found that those with cameras used force at about the same rate as those without.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a series of high-profile police shootings, police departments across the nation turned to body cameras, hoping they would curb abuses. But a rigorous study released Friday shows that they have almost no effect on officer behavior.
articles.byline: By Amanda Ripley and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: Conflicting Accounts in Niger Ambush Are Subject of Pentagon Investigation
articles.snippet: Nigerien officials have said that a convoy gave chase to Islamic militants who later returned to ambush them, but American troops say they didn’t pursue the militants before the attack.
articles.abstract: Nigerien officials have said that a convoy gave chase to Islamic militants who later returned to ambush them, but American troops say they didn’t pursue the militants before the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon is trying to determine whether American forces involved in a deadly ambush in Niger this month diverted from their routine patrol to embark on an unapproved mission, military officials said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: The Finger-Pointing at the Finance Firm TIAA
articles.snippet: Ex-employees and whistle-blowers question whether the provider of investment advice to people in public and nonprofit jobs does put its customers first.
articles.abstract: Ex-employees and whistle-blowers question whether the provider of investment advice to people in public and nonprofit jobs does put its customers first.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the treacherous world of finance, where investors confront biased advice, hidden costs and onerous fees, one investment giant seems to stand apart — the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, also known as TIAA. Calling itself a “mission-based organization” with a “nonprofit heritage,” TIAA has enjoyed a reputation as a selfless steward of its clients’ assets for almost a century.

articles.headline: Spain Will Remove Catalonia Leader, Escalating Secession Crisis
articles.snippet: Mariano Rajoy, in an unexpectedly forceful move, said Madrid would take control of the independence-minded region, pushing out its separatist administration.
articles.abstract: Mariano Rajoy, in an unexpectedly forceful move, said Madrid would take control of the independence-minded region, pushing out its separatist administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — The escalating confrontation over Catalonia’s independence drive took its most serious turn on Saturday as Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain announced he would remove the leadership of the restive region and initiate a process of direct rule by the central government in Madrid.

articles.headline: Why Has the E.P.A. Shifted on Toxic Chemicals? An Industry Insider Helps Call the Shots
articles.snippet: A scientist who worked for the chemical industry now shapes policy on hazardous chemicals. Within the E.P.A., there is fear that public health is at risk. (At right, a signing ceremony for new rules on toxic chemicals.)
articles.abstract: A scientist who worked for the chemical industry now shapes policy on hazardous chemicals. Within the E.P.A., there is fear that public health is at risk. (At right, a signing ceremony for new rules on toxic chemicals.)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, the Environmental Protection Agency has struggled to prevent an ingredient once used in stain-resistant carpets and nonstick pans from contaminating drinking water.

articles.headline: Conservatives, With Bannon’s Help, Look for Revenge in Mississippi
articles.snippet: A brewing Republican vs. Republican fight could test whether the anti-incumbent insurgency backed by Stephen K. Bannon becomes a credible national movement.
articles.abstract: A brewing Republican vs. Republican fight could test whether the anti-incumbent insurgency backed by Stephen K. Bannon becomes a credible national movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAUREL, Miss. — In the recent history of Republican infighting, few losses have been more bitter than Chris McDaniel’s. Mr. McDaniel, a Mississippi state senator, still nurses the conviction that he was robbed of a seat in the United States Senate in 2014 by a Republican establishment that race-baited, covered up his opponent’s affair and encouraged Democrats to raid the primary.

articles.headline: Bill O’Reilly Settled New Harassment Claim, Then Fox Renewed His Contract
articles.snippet: In January, the Fox News host was said to have agreed to a $32 million settlement with a former network analyst, the largest of his known payouts.
articles.abstract: In January, the Fox News host was said to have agreed to a $32 million settlement with a former network analyst, the largest of his known payouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last January, six months after Fox News ousted its chairman amid a sexual harassment scandal, the network’s top-rated host at the time, Bill O’Reilly, struck a $32 million agreement with a longtime network analyst to settle new sexual harassment allegations, according to two people briefed on the matter — an extraordinarily large amount for such cases.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Iran Saps Strength of Revolutionary Guards With Arrests and Cutbacks
articles.snippet: The elite military group drove the Iranian economy at the peak of the sanctions era. Now, seen as a drag on growth, it is under attack by President Hassan Rouhani.
articles.abstract: The elite military group drove the Iranian economy at the peak of the sanctions era. Now, seen as a drag on growth, it is under attack by President Hassan Rouhani.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — From its nine-story headquarters in an upscale neighborhood of Tehran, a giant construction company directs its operations across Iran, building mosques, airports, oil and gas installations, hospitals, and skyscrapers.

articles.headline: A Newly Assertive C.I.A. Expands Its Taliban Hunt in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The assignment heralds a shift for the agency, which once viewed such a mission as risky and a drain on resources.
articles.abstract: The assignment heralds a shift for the agency, which once viewed such a mission as risky and a drain on resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. is expanding its covert operations in Afghanistan, sending small teams of highly experienced officers and contractors alongside Afghan forces to hunt and kill Taliban militants across the country, according to two senior American officials, the latest sign of the agency’s increasingly integral role in President Trump’s counterterrorism strategy.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Xi Jinping Pushes China’s Rise Despite Friction and Fear
articles.snippet: Mr. Xi has enjoyed remarkable success expanding Chinese global influence, benefiting from President Trump’s election. But he is also facing pushback to his assertive approach to foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Mr. Xi has enjoyed remarkable success expanding Chinese global influence, benefiting from President Trump’s election. But he is also facing pushback to his assertive approach to foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — No part of the world seems too small, too near or too far for China’s globe-trotting president, Xi Jinping.

articles.headline: Still Waiting for FEMA in Texas and Florida After Hurricanes
articles.snippet: After Harvey and Irma, residents are waiting weeks for FEMA inspections and hours on hold when calling the agency’s help line.
articles.abstract: After Harvey and Irma, residents are waiting weeks for FEMA inspections and hours on hold when calling the agency’s help line.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Outside Rachel Roberts’s house, a skeleton sits on a chair next to the driveway, a skeleton child on its lap, an empty cup in its hand and a sign at its feet that reads “Waiting on FEMA.”
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Lizette Alvarez and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: A Showdown Brews Between Amazon and Alibaba, Far From Home
articles.snippet: The e-commerce giants are spending billions in new markets like Southeast Asia and India to tap a rising new class of young, middle-class shoppers.
articles.abstract: The e-commerce giants are spending billions in new markets like Southeast Asia and India to tap a rising new class of young, middle-class shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — From this concrete warehouse perched on the edge of a potentially vast new market for online shopping, the Alibaba Group of China hopes to beat Amazon one head of lettuce at a time.

articles.headline: Tech Giants Are Paying Huge Salaries for Scarce A.I. Talent
articles.snippet: Nearly all big tech companies have an artificial intelligence project, and they are willing to pay experts millions of dollars to help get it done.
articles.abstract: Nearly all big tech companies have an artificial intelligence project, and they are willing to pay experts millions of dollars to help get it done.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley’s start-ups have always had a recruiting advantage over the industry’s giants: Take a chance on us and we’ll give you an ownership stake that could make you rich if the company is successful.

articles.headline: At BuzzFeed, a Pivot to Movies and Television
articles.snippet: Matthew Henick, a onetime teenage ringtone magnate, is leading the company away from popular shorts toward deals with production studios.
articles.abstract: Matthew Henick, a onetime teenage ringtone magnate, is leading the company away from popular shorts toward deals with production studios.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — On an October morning, Matthew Henick, the head of BuzzFeed Motion Pictures, maneuvered his black Lexus S.U.V. through thick Los Angeles traffic from his home in Silver Lake toward BuzzFeed’s new campus, still under construction, in Hollywood.

articles.headline: Hopes Dim for Congressional Russia Inquiries as Parties Clash
articles.snippet: Three congressional investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 election have run into serious obstacles, and definitive conclusions are now unlikely.
articles.abstract: Three congressional investigations into Russian interference in the 2016 election have run into serious obstacles, and definitive conclusions are now unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a secured room in the basement of the Capitol in July, Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, fielded question after question from members of the House Intelligence Committee. Though the allotted time for the grilling had expired, he offered to stick around as long as they wanted.

articles.headline: Where Internet Orders Mean Real Jobs, and New Life for Communities
articles.snippet: Vast warehouses are being built, fueling a demand for lower-skilled workers and reviving areas that once relied on manufacturing.
articles.abstract: Vast warehouses are being built, fueling a demand for lower-skilled workers and reviving areas that once relied on manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — Ellen Gaugler remembers driving her father to the Bethlehem Steel mill, where he spent his working years hauling beams off the assembly line and onto rail cars.

articles.headline: A Long-Delayed Reckoning of the Cost of Silence on Abuse
articles.snippet: One reason we’re just hearing about harassment claims against Harvey Weinstein and Bill O’Reilly has to do with nondisclosure agreements signed by the accusers.
articles.abstract: One reason we’re just hearing about harassment claims against Harvey Weinstein and Bill O’Reilly has to do with nondisclosure agreements signed by the accusers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill O’Reilly and Harvey Weinstein may have come from different ends of the political spectrum, but it turns out they have a lot in common.

articles.headline: Tesla Plant in China May Be a First
articles.snippet: Tesla is said to be moving closer to becoming the first foreign car company to have a wholly owned manufacturing operation in the country.
articles.abstract: Tesla is said to be moving closer to becoming the first foreign car company to have a wholly owned manufacturing operation in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Tesla is moving closer to becoming the first foreign car company to have a wholly owned manufacturing operation in China, a deal that would test the relationship norms between a foreign automaker and the Chinese government.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: China’s New Antipollution Push Could Cool Its Growth Engine
articles.snippet: Chinese officials face tough choices as they move to clean up skies and rivers, an effort that some say could put downward pressure on the economy.
articles.abstract: Chinese officials face tough choices as they move to clean up skies and rivers, an effort that some say could put downward pressure on the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Through the last four decades, China has achieved breathtaking economic growth at the cost of smoggy skies, fetid streams and lakes of dying fish.

articles.headline: What It Could Mean if China’s Leader Won’t Name an Heir
articles.snippet: If no successors-in-waiting appear, that would raise speculation that Xi Jinping may try to keep power in some form after his second five-year term as president ends.
articles.abstract: If no successors-in-waiting appear, that would raise speculation that Xi Jinping may try to keep power in some form after his second five-year term as president ends.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When President Xi Jinping of China walks into the Great Hall of the People this week to reveal the team of leaders who will help him rule China for the next half decade, all eyes will be on whether the lineup includes one or two younger faces in the running to become his successor.

articles.headline: Latest Bill O’Reilly Case Is ‘Jaw-Dropping,’ Megyn Kelly Says
articles.snippet: Needing a ratings boost, the host of “Megyn Kelly Today” targets what she calls a culture of sexual harassment at her former employer.
articles.abstract: Needing a ratings boost, the host of “Megyn Kelly Today” targets what she calls a culture of sexual harassment at her former employer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unusual attack on a former employer, the NBC host Megyn Kelly used her morning show on Monday to denounce her former Fox News colleague Bill O’Reilly and the cable network where she used to work.
